title: 112_hr3829
content: The "Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012" or the "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires a criminal background check for child care providers under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates criminal background checks for child care staff, family child care providers, and adults living in the home of a family child care provider in states receiving funds under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act. The checks include searches of national and state criminal databases, as well as abuse and neglect registries. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires criminal background checks for child care providers, including searches of national and state criminal databases, abuse and neglect registries, and FBI fingerprint checks. Providers are ineligible for funds if a background check reveals certain felony convictions related to child abuse, spousal abuse, crimes against children, or violent crimes. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates criminal background checks for child care providers, including searches of national and state criminal databases, abuse and neglect registries, and FBI fingerprint checks. Providers are disqualified from receiving funds if their background check shows felony convictions related to child abuse, spousal abuse, crimes against children, violent crimes, or drug offenses within the past 5 years. Child care providers must request a State and national criminal background check through the designated State agency for staff members or individuals residing in their private residence. The Child Care Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 requires background checks for child care providers and individuals residing in their private residence. Checks must be done before the state implements the requirements and every 5 years thereafter for existing staff members. Prospective staff members must undergo checks before starting their roles. The Child Care Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 mandates background checks for child care staff and residents in their private homes. Checks are required before the law takes effect and every 5 years thereafter. Only one check is needed per 5-year period for each individual. Results must be provided within 10 business days of the request. The law mandates background checks for child care staff and residents in private homes every 5 years. Results must be provided within 10 business days of the request, and a copy of the background check can be obtained upon request. States must ensure the accuracy and completeness of the information in the background check. The State must ensure the accuracy of background check information by obtaining dispositions of arrests over 1 year old, correcting inaccuracies, completing incomplete entries, and taking steps to improve accuracy. Individuals can appeal background check results to the designated State agency within 30 days. "Child care providers or individuals can appeal background check results to the State agency within 30 days. The State must determine eligibility, provide specific findings, make changes to inaccurate information if possible, and report these changes to the individual. A State may collect one fee to cover the costs of these duties." The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 allows child care providers to appeal background check results within 30 days. States must determine eligibility, provide specific findings, make changes to inaccurate information, and report these changes to the individual. States can collect a fee not exceeding $36 per criminal background check to cover administrative costs. States must implement these requirements within 3 years of the Act's enactment, with a possible 2-year extension granted by the Secretary for good faith efforts. The Secretary may grant a 2-year extension to a State making a good faith effort to meet the requirements of the Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012. Definitions in this section include 'adult' as a person over 18 years old, 'child care provider' as a licensed provider of child care services, and 'child care staff member' as an individual providing child care services for compensation. The term 'family child care provider' refers to an individual who provides child care services for fewer than 24 hours per day in a private residence, is not related to all children in their care, and is licensed, regulated, or receives funds under State law. The term 'family child care provider' refers to an individual who provides child care services in a private residence for children and is licensed, regulated, or funded under State law. Authorization of appropriations is provided for conducting criminal background checks.
